Three of us ventured here on Saturday September 19, 2015 before the Angel Arm's Bar Bounce.  I ordered three pancakes, no butter, added powdered sugar and sugar free syrup- delicious!  I needed a kick of protein so I went w/ two poached eggs- I enjoyed my meal.  

The service was friendly but it took some time for the food to be delivered and one in our party never received his hashbrowns...  he wasn't upset and they took it off the bill at checkout.   

The gal running around refilling water was on it!  

The people watching is quite good, the line moved quickly, I would eat here again and most definitely order the pancakes.

If you are wanting GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE, then sorry, this place isn't it.
If you want cheap, fast, great tasting diner food then this is the place.
The pancakes taste like huge, fluffy clouds. I crave their pancakes.This is the perfect dive breakfast restaurant in STL. Plus I've never had issues with customer service. Everyone has been nice to me.

Uncle Bill's may be just like one of those untidy distant relatives that makes you cringe just a little when it comes to hygiene. But you like keeping company with them every once in a while.  I believe the stories shared that go along with this local haunt...adventurous eating to be sure.

I stumbled across this breakfast institution on the way to Laumeier Sculpture Park. And I'd recommend a visit to Bill's even if you don't also seek out the sculpture.

To be fair to Bill's and yelpers alike, the food I and my guest selected was as expected.  I went biscuits and gravy, while my guest took on the pork chop and eggs.  The service was very good too.

Bill's could almost make the best of the breakfast scene list--only a three star food experience, as their offerings were a great value for the low prices.  Bill's might be an even better haunt for their late night crowd...this earns Bill's that fourth star for me. St. Louis may have better breakfast to offer, and I look forward to finding them.

My partner and I come here at least once a month, generally in the late evening or overnight hours.  We aren't the biggest fan of how they seat people but we deal for the food. If you're wondering, typically they put everyone right next to one another. I understand the reasoning but it would be nice if there was like a booth between people or something if they aren't busy. Also, being placed next to a couple of small children at 11PM is not cool either. They were cranky and noisy -- just not what we were wanting to hear all throughout our meal. Again, not the restaurant's fault necessarily, just an annoyance!!

Now, the food. We always have a good, consistent experience here. Recently I asked for gravy on my biscuits and didn't get it, but they were good about taking the gravy off the bill. Everything is delicious -- like mom makes. If you're looking for a variety of options to go with your typical bacon and eggs look no further. Our personal favorite is the "juicy burger" with two eggs. It comes with hashbrowns and your choice of biscuits, toast or pancakes. I usually get biscuits and add gravy. Delicious and totally hits the spot if you're looking for good breakfast food. We haven't really ordered off the dinner/lunch menu so I don't know what that's like. They have EXCELLENT coffee.

If you're looking for a gourmet experience, this is not it. It's for when you're craving something and don't want to make it at home. 

It can get a bit pricy (they add on gratuity after a certain point in the evening and we tip on top of that) which we aren't the biggest fans of. We can usually go to Courtesy Diner and spend the same amount for way more food. Still, it works for what it is.

Superbly quick and delicious. Price is fair for being in a major city. Staff is friendly and will get you served up right. Most all the egg dishes come with pancakes!! I mean who couldn't love that!? Thank you!

This a great place for breakfast, wether there's just two of you or if you want a group. It's pretty old school, in a good way, and prices are right. It took me long time to check it out and I was missing out. I will be going back.

The happy memories I had coming here in my early 20's were surely fogged by many drinks. Coming here around 2am when you are in your  "over thirties" isn't quite the same experience. We were seated at a long table but were quickly moved after some vomiting occurred ON the table next to us.  
I was happy they moved us!

After that the experience wasn't great but it wasn't awful either. The food was "food" when you are starving after dancing the night away with your gal pals. It wasn't horrible but what does it say when you DON'T eat your second piece of BACON? It's 2am... I have had a few cocktails (not the driver) and I should be wolfing down that other bacon strip like it was the last one on earth.  No thanks, too "chewy" like its been sitting for a long long long time.
The french toast I ordered was filling, but nothing to write home about.
They did make it easy for us to all get separate checks, so that was nice.

Note- Your tip is automatically added to the bill after midnight. I didn't see that til I was already up at the register.  They must get tipped really well there!!!! ;)
Has Uncles Bills lost its luster?? People waiting in line with lots of open tables? Out of Chocolate Milk? Orange juice is off.  Service is so slow.  Wow.

This place is exactly what I want for breakfast all the time. I've even thought about moving back to St. Louis so I can be wrapped in the embrace of 60's faux wood paneling while eating a delicious and cheap breakfast.

Definitely a favorite. The best place to go after a night of drinking and poor choices. Just the best greasy diner food you could ask for, served quickly, 24 hours a day. I even like the sassy wait staff.

You get a lot for such a low price 

This place had some of the fluffiest pancakes that I've ever had...they were really good but filled me up fast. I also had the Western Omelette which was as good and filled me up as much as the pancakes. The service wasn't bad though I've had better. The walls (at least where I was sitting) had all types of neat pictures of different landmarks around St. Louis. One should definitely check out Uncle Bill's for a good, hardy breakfast...but you may not be hungry again until dinner time.

If you want to people watch at 1am, then Uncle Bill's is going to show you some sh*&t. This place gets 4 stars for the WTF factor. Crazy collection of after hours revelers in vary degrees of depression and coherence. Then there is a random table of sober older folks who I have no idea how they choose this place and where they came from. The food is actually pretty good. The wheat pancakes are really good. I had the standard breakfast fare of eggs, hash browns, and basically more food then one should consume at 1am. The service was excellent. What those servers must put up with in the bleak morning hours and still stay attentive and cordial. Kudos to a hard job that is well done. If I were grading this on class, it is definitely classier than Courtesy but not at all as hipster as City Diner. If you were wondering...
The pancakes were ok, but nothing extraordinary. But the eggs and the bacon were unlike any I've ever had- cooked TOTALLY to perfection.The service was excellent-fast,courteous and professional.

Nothing he is worth writing about from a positive experience. The food was bland and I have had far better meals at the Waffle House at 3 am. The waitresses were sub standard and thankfully for them I always tip because if I tipped based on service they would not get a dollar from me. There are many other far better diners in the area such as Goody Goody that are happy to have you as a customer. I would have been better off going through the drive thru at McDonald's rather than have wasted my time and money eating here.
Have some pancakes.  A short stack is really plenty.  Syrup on the plate, not your pants.  Remember that, and you'll be fine.

The food was delicious and freshly prepared. Fluffy pancakes, eggs scrambled just right, and hot sausage and bacon. I'll definitely be back. The only downside was the hour wait to get our food. I understand that it was the wee hours of New Year's Day, but staffing should have been planned to mitigate this kind of delay.
I like breakfast food. Uncle bills serves breakfast food. I don't remember exactly what I had, but I do remember being satisfied and happy with a cheap bill. Would go again.

If I had to describe what the best food in a weekend would consist of in St. Louis, I have to include Uncle Bills.  Best Breakfast food in the entire city hands down.  At least if you are the traditional pancakes- eggs-bacon-and-suasage kind of guy like me.  
After a late night and a morning of debating over where we should go for brunch, we settled upon Uncle Bills on Kingshighway (there is another location in West County).  
I had the ham and cheese omelette, and it was hearty and delicious.  It's just a couple slices of american cheese cooked in with the ham and eggs, but it really gets the job done.  And the pancakes are out of this world delicious.  They come out hot and everything is served as soon as it is ready, so you don't have to wait long for your food.  
And you don't have to wait long for:  THE BACON!!  Bacon, bacon, bacon.  Is there any better food than bacon?  The answer is no.  Uncle Bill's serves up hearty, thick slices of bacon that will knock your socks off, and knock that hangover off too!  Oh goodness, there is nothing I won't eat that contains bacon.  
The bacon fest is even more aperbo at this place becuase it feels like you are back at grandma's house when you were a kid - at least the decor makes you feel that way.  Grandma always made the best bacon.  
Anyways, I didn't get to try the hash browns, but the guy's plate next to us had me drooling for them, but I ate too much bacon so I didn't get to try them.  
Hit up Uncle Bill's if you are a breakfast lover like me.  You will not be disappointed.
Wonderful food and environment, but be prepared for a wait and slightly more than you might pay else where.

The pancakes alone are worth 4 stars because they are consistently better than the pancakes I have at other breakfast joints. That batter has to be made fresh every hour with lots of love or something. Something, I wish I knew why these pancakes or so much better than all the other pancakes I've had. Moving on, customer service is hit or miss but quit complaining man the place is 24/7. I'm actually not a fan of the regular bacon here. The Canadian bacon is much better. I remember that I was not a fan of their prices. However, I was in college at the time so that might have affected my perception - you know cause I was broke.

How can you complain about a big ol' plate of breakfast grub and endless pots of coffee?  You can't!!!

Had a traditional breakfast platter consisting of eggs, meats, potatoes and (of course!) pancakes.  It was enough to feed a small army, and all tasted as you'd expect from a place known for their diner-style breakfasts.  I especially liked their thick-cut bacon and the pancakes were hearty and filling.

Two thumbs up, Uncle Bill!

The wait was not long, especially for a Sunday morning. Service was fairly quick considering they were very busy. The food took a little bit of time to get to the table but not a terribly long time. The pancakes were delicious. The omelet I ordered, a bacon and cheese one, was horrid! The bacon was half raw inside. Waitress ignored the fact that it set there uneaten, except with 1 bite out of it. Never asked if anything was wrong.

Chicken fried chicken with gravy was tasty - wish the biscuits were home made though.
Taste doesn't live up to the price ($70 for 4 ppl)
I don't think its as gross as some of the reviewers make it out to be, it's your basic south side 24/7 diner that looks more like a resturaunt. For your basic breakfast, you can't go wrong.

Forgive my tofu, sashimi, nights with polenta. Forgive soy lattes, Utne Reader, and gluten-free. Never again. Epiphany. Uncle Bill's Pancake House. I am reborn. American cheese. 

Turkey omelette (spelling matters little during revelation) was the best I've ever had. Fluffy, not just glorified scrambled eggs. Hash browns, I can not describe without uttering holy names. (Ketchup: provided.) Pancakes, what we all seek, were too salty for my taste, but still good, very good. And the portion size: seas of plenty. 

Service was cheery, sunny, just perfect. Who can frown in a place like this? Coffee topped up as soon as I took a sip -- we could get into a parenthetical about coffee top-ups disrupting the carefully mixed Brown Ratio coffee:sugar:creamer, but that's just angels on a pinhead type stuff -- and there was creamer, in white paper capsules, and I forgot all about soy milk. 

I thought the guy eating at the next table was Jimmy Buffett gone wrong. He had wonderfully dyed-in-a-sink "blonde" hair on leathery tanned  skin, and prefaced everything he said to his dining companion with the invective "PAY ATTENTION!" Jimmy Buffett loses his recording contract, switches from margaritas to heroin, ends up having to move to St Louis, and bingo, here we are! 

Just outside the front door, there was a 1980 Ford LTD, parked somewhat diagonally. I thought of the Beastie Boys video: Sabotage! I wanted to hop in, put on my mirrored aviators (at 4 AM), and drive off into the sunrise. But that's the hash browns talking.

Been coming here for years....always after hours though, not sure if I could even find the place during the day, he he he. However I've been the sober driver in many occasions and even then I think Uncle Bills is very tasty, it definitely holds a special place in my heart, I love everything on that giant menu.

We took the whole family here the morning we left St. Louis. Yes, the decor was a bit dated but we were sat almost immediately and this was on a Sunday morning. It really depeneds how many are in your party. There were lots of couples waiting to be seated but we had 5 so it only took a few minutes to seat us. 

My kids ordered from the kids menu, I had Bill's Skillet which was yummy. My hubby and daughter had omelettes. The food was really good and yes a tad bit greasy.  They always came and checked our coffee cups to see if we needed refills which was nice. All in all, it was a nice place to have breakfast. 

Keep in mind, the restaurant has smoking (but we sat in NON). Reasonable prices, and nice servers.

BREAKFAST/LUNCH/DINNER & every meal in between. Uncle Bill's on standby! Open 24hours, but rarely an EMPTY table in sight. In peak operations, lines spew outside and wrap the building. All are welcome in Bill's House.

Old school, roadside diner setup. Wood panelling lines the interior, making me feel like a nephew visiting my UNCLE. Sit down, the waitresses call you 'honey' and things similar. Coffee requests are always first priority...Lawd', give me strength...Enjoy a cup of joe(or two) with your meal. GET HYPED !  

All-Star cast of featured menu options, visiting every possible corner of the FoodSpectrum®. From hash-browns & omelettes, to their signature Patty Melt, Bill has you covered. 

***Bring your friends late-nite, take the family after church, or just ride solo to catch the morning paper. Behold, Uncle Bill's Pancake and Dinner House, the spirit of American dining***

it's trashy, it's dirty, the service is less than perfect, and the food is greasy, what better place to enjoy a late night meal than right at Uncle Bills.  There really aren't too many late night eat places that cater well to drunks and the night owls but Uncle Bills is always right there ready and waiting for you.

The building hasn't changed in looks in all of the years I have been going, and I really don't expect that it will change, it's honestly what makes this place the dive that it is.. I really don't like the pancakes which is supposedly what they specialize in since it IS a pancake house, however the eggs, and slingers, and everything else hits the spot on those late nights.

Don't expect a top restaurant when you walk into Uncle Bills, because it's far from that. but do expect to go in, get some fast food, and maybe even have a little fun and entertainment...

You just finished your night around town, possibly drunk, and in need of some food.  Uncle Bill's to the rescue.

So lets see, they:

are always open - 24/7 - check
start you off with a pitcher of water - check
are courteous when you may not be quite so capable of it - check
have the food you want - check
cheap - check

But really, this place is great for a meal at any time of the day or night.  The menu is pretty extensive with the classic diner foods, and some not so typical additions.  The potato pancakes for example are really good.  The food is generally well done, definitely a step above Denny's and the like.  The place is relatively clean, the atmosphere is friendly, so if you feel like some good American food, this is the place for you.

I am a breakfast (old diner style - not quiche style) connoisseur - Uncle Bill's rocked it. I'm going to assume that a lot of butter was involved - but it really doesn't matter in a place like this. You know going in that this isn't going to be "good for you" - no, it's GOOD for you. A very subtle yet important distinction. :-)

Pancakes are truly cakes. I could have eaten them without syrup (I never put butter on them anyway). The bacon was some of the best I've ever had - thick, smokey and melt in your mouth. 

The waitstaff's cranky yet sweet attitude was reminiscent of another time. I'm leaving full and happy. Well worth a little detour off of I44.

Theft??????? 
I haven't been to Uncle Bill's yet myself but yesterday afternoon my wife, mother, and my daughter went to Uncle Bill's for lunch. 
All three meals were under $10 each plus around $2-3 drinks. The bill was and should have been around $30. Somehow, the final amount changed to the credit card was close to $50..... 
Wow, I am pretty sure that the sales tax isn't 63%. I asked wife for the receipt and she said that she wasn't given one. 
She said that when the check came they paid most of the tip in cash and added an additional $2 tip to the credit card bill as well, but hadn't signed it yet and it was taken away and somehow out of sight the bill jumped up $20. Strange?  Seems like an extra zero got added somewhere. 
It may have just been an error and not insinuating anything, but it does seem like a $2 tip magically became a $20 tip.

This my 3rd time eating breakfast here. Good was always very good, service was great and restaurant was nice and clean. I had eggs bacon hash browns biscuits gravy and coffee. My dining partner and I shared one order of gravy. Very full and satisfied when we left. I love this place.

I have eaten here numerous occasions, and if you have not yet tried Uncle Bill's, you need to see what the fuss is about. With an abundant number of menu choices, you can keep coming back without fear of getting bored with the same menu items other diners serve.

It's 24 hours...which is very convenient for those who work at night.

I love their pancakes (I love pineapple, so the pineapple pancakes are one of my favorites). This location stays busy throughout the day and night, but you can still expect to get prompt service and hot food out a lot faster than you would expect when it's busy. 
I personally have never had any problems in my numerous visits, so I'm a little surprised at some of the negative reviews.

the 1-star is because they're open all night...other than that, it was not good AT ALL!!!  i ordered an omelet with spinach & mushrooms...they may have well just brought me the egg-in-a-shell...the eggs were pretty runny and the omelet was gross-looking, so i told the waitress my concern and asked to have it cooked more...the 2nd time back, it STILL was not cooked properly...so, i was done! i had pancakes (which came with the omelet)...can't really mess those up...at least i got SOMEthing on my stomach, after a long night of partying!

If you want an old time diner breakfast with awesome pancakes and diner breakfast food - then this is your place. 

The atmosphere is old  outdated with wood paneling - but that's the charm of an old diner - the staff has probably been working there since they were in high school - they were friendly and helpful 

Wish I had been there for lunch as I think their pie would've been a treat! 

This is now our goto breakfast place when we are in town

Eeeew?  Once upon a time, Uncle Bill's was the only clean option for late night drunks who didn't want to go home.  Now, we have something called 3AM bars, a strew of late night eateries and well, Uncle Bill's sucks.

It's dated (not in a good way), scuzzy, and 1/2 of the food is on the walls & floor.  Last time I was tipsy enough to get talked into Uncle Bill's, we were seated at a filthy table.  When they came to wipe off our dirty table,  the waitress sprayed the table with cleanser while we were sitting there and it ended up tasting better than the food.

I am from a small town and this is exactly what I would expect to find there. A place where you are greeted, there are Halloween stickers on the window and there are those around you reading the paper drinking their coffee. 

The prices are affordable; it was $20 for two stacks of pancakes and two sides of hash browns, which turned out to be more than either of us could eat in one sitting. My recommendation is to share the stack of pancakes because that is most likely the only way they are going to get finished. I had the pecan and he had the buttermilk and though they were a bit greasy, they were hot off the skillet and just like my mom would make them.

They serve the best pancake in St. Louis. It is only after you visit this place and eat their pancakes, you will realize why they have won the best pancake house award for 22 consecutive years. And you don't have to worry about the timings as it open 24x7. So, if you ever dream of pancakes in the middle of the night, this is your go-to place.

We have always driven by here and see the long line waiting to get in.  We always wanted to try it... and yesterday we did.  We waited in a long line with a light drisle of rain.  The line moved fairly quickly, only about a 20 minute wait.  

It was worth it.  i was hungry but not hungry for the famous pancakes that everyone goes on and on aboout.  I had a grilled cheese sandwhich with fries.  Scott had the country fried steak, that came with hashbrowns as well as pancakes.  I tried the pancackes... because I had nothing to lose.  I dont like pancakes, we had them to often when I was a kid.  But let me tell you... these are the best pancakes I have ever had.  They were so light, yet very tasteful.  Cooked to perfection.  I honeslty might go back just to have the pancakes.

I recommend this as a great breakfast place.... keep in mind they cook their whole menu 24/7.  So day or night you can try them. :)

This is my favorite breakfast place in StL. The food is cheap, and you get a lot of it. The place is open 24 hours, and can cure any hangover. The eggs, omelettes and pancakes are all delicious. The service is usually decent too.

Not the prettiest place in the world but the food is good for the reasonable prices they offer. 

I had bacon, Canadian bacon and scrambled eggs and they were great. My wife had French toast, eggs and hash browns and though she felt the toast was too bready, I tried it and loved it. 

Not many places offering 24/7 breakfast in St. Louis but this place is worth the drive.

I ordered Uncle Bill's Skillet and my partner ordered the blueberry pancakes.  The pancakes here are worth a try.  Large and covered in copious amounts of fresh toppings. The bacon strips are also thick and huge. This place fills up fast, however, we were there on a Sunday morning and only waited about 5 minutes for a table.  Staff is all kind. Typical favorite breakfast joint.

Food = good
Service = eh depends on your sense of humor

In search of biscuits and gravy at 2:00 p.m. on Saturday... Where oh where can you go? Uncle Bill's to the rescue.  I figure if I can get biscuits and gravy at 2:00 a.m. I can get em at 2:00 p.m.  I was right.

The food was just as expected- good, greasy and cheap.

Best part was when I asked one of the girls refilling the sugar if I could possibly get some sweetener for my coffee... only to be greeted with somewhat of a glare.  She did bring me sweetener though, and threw it on the table with a defiant "here".  

I just giggled- this is what I expect from Uncle Bill's.

It was after midnight. I was playing chauffer and I wasn't very hungry. 

Uncle Bill's epitomizes pancake dive. The walls are dark. The floor is carpeted. It feels but doesn't smell smoky. It feels so - 60s? It attracted every age and manner of person on a Saturday evening. 

Breakfast food isn't really my thing, so I ordered ice cream to go with my hash browns. Prices are decent. Wish they offered baked potatoes all times of day. 

I have finally been to Uncle Bill's!

Uncle Bill's is the ultimate 24 hour breakfast stop. It's got the decorations to make you nostalgic, service to make you smile, and a varied enough menu to satisfy whatever variety of high calorie and soul warming breakfast you could desire. 

I've tried this place a few times and I really like the corned beef hash as well as the breakfast skillet. Basically, I like meat and hash browns with eggs on top. The coffee is good and plentiful. I love the fluffy biscuits here plus they give you lots of whipped butter. The pancakes are fairly tasty as well! 

My only complaints are I like my eggs over easy and I've had them over cooked here multiple times. I wish prices were just a little less as well. 

Be prepared for a wait if you go at prime breakfast or brunch time on weekends!

Went on a night with a very popular production being put on at the Fox so it was packed. We got seated in the lobby as they call it - not the atmosphere of the diner but that was okay as we needed to eat and get on to the Fox. The entire table ordered french onion soup which was excellent - deep spicy flavor. Two of us split the turkey club and the others quesadilla. Both were well liked but not memorable. The only disappointment was the Irish coffees we ordered - it turned out to be some whiskey with coffee which isn't the complete Irish coffee recipe and the coffee was much more stronger than the whiskey which makes me doubt the amount of whiskey put into the mug. Service was execellent - Sierra was our waitress and I would highly recommend her.

The only reason I'm giving 1 star is because I need to in order to write a review.
Please don't bother giving this place your business.  We just had the worst dining experience ever.  4 moms and all our kids after Circus Flora for lunch. We walked in, and when we told the hostess there would be 12 of us, she immediately was giving us trouble on how to arrange the tables, saying we couldn't sit or arrange a certain way, she was rude.  We ordered our food and I'm not kidding it took an hour.  4 families came in, ordered, ate and left, before we got our food.  My friend received her food along with her children's first, and the burger and fries were cold.  Then it took them another 10 minutes to bring the rest of our party our food. When I went to check on where the food was, the waiter was incredibly snippy with me.  It's a diner - cheap and easy food should not have taken that long.  I'm convinced they held our food on purpose.

They apologized and said they had a mad rush and weren't used to that.  Yes you are - you are used to people eating there before and after the theater all the time.

I was so excited when City Diner opened up at the Fox. I am a sucker for their chicken fingers and even more of a sucker for their onion rings. There have actually been times when I've ordered just a plate of onion rings for dinner....so worth it. Every time I have been here the staff has been super friendly and even when they are crazy busy (which is often) I always feel like they are willing to get me seated as quickly as possible. My favorite spot to sit at is definitely the bar. It could be my imagination but for some reason I actually feel like I get more moving around room over in that section. The last time I went right before heading over to see a show at the Fox I got my onion rings and the server suggested I try sprinkling a little bit of sugar on one of them because according to here it would make it taste similarly to a Vietnamese donut....Holy delicious she was so right! I only did that for one or 2 but it was a nice surprise, and now I really need to stop righting this because I am seriously craving some onion rings now.

The original is always good. Unfortunately, this isn't. The omelet I ordered had more oil than egg. When I asked them to remake it without oil, they evened out the oil to egg ratio to 1:1. I almost never leave food on my plate and I don't mind greasy, but this was inedible. Go to the original for a few months until they either hire a new chef or train this one.

I went here late night with my girlfriends - my first time going here and well it will simply be my last. 

Right as we walked in the hostess looks at us and is seems overwhelmed in how to seat us. Excuse you, white lady who was hosting that night, there were only five of us, not that difficult. Just put two tables together. However, this woman says, "I'm gonna have to go to the back... brb" and goes to the back, making us wait for 12 minutes (yes, I timed you) then talked to a waiter (who was helping her solve this rocket science equation) saying, "yeah, it seems we have no choice but to put it together." And with her oh so genius partner they connect two tables together and sat us down. 

Was that so hard? Well golly! Slap my redneck ass and drink a jug of moonshine because that was oh so difficult for you people to figure out! 

So we sit there, waiting for a waiter to come take our order and it takes us 15 minutes. Um, those who are fans of City Diner will probably say, "bitch please, this place is packed with people." Um, matter of fact no, it wasn't packed at all. There were only 4 other tables who already had their food and were about done. So after our good old 15 minutes of twiddling our thumbs, we get this waiter who gets our order and it takes a good amount of time for it to come out. 

However, the food was nothing to be special about. I ordered the turkey club sandwich and though it was pretty big (no complaints) it wasn't that good (complaint). My friend ordered chilli with some fries - which I think the fries were good but not so much of the chilli. Also another friend got a simple cheeseburger and it didn't look that great. The milkshakes just looked like icecream too - like they were too lazy to make it into an actual shake and just gave it to us to make it. Also when we split the check, the waiter had such a hard time. He even told us, "It will take about 20 minutes." 

20 minutes. 

Wow, ok genius. Go ahead and take your sweet ass time. 

So what good came out of this... hmm, it would have to be the french fries and the whole scenery of people rushing into the Fox Theater (which I love). Those are the only best things. The food and service - I shall look for it elsewhere.
This place is disgusting! Everytime I eat here I end up with nausea and/or diarrhea. I will never eat here again. I don't even want a glass of water out of this place.
Bad service. The coach is very old and kind of dirty. Food is disappointed. Never come again.
Service was very slow, restaurant was understaffed. Food was bland, burnt, and just not very good overall. I won't be returning and don't recommend you do.

I'm going to tell you when to come to the City Diner at the Fox, not have to wait and get quick and wonderful service. You ready? Saturday morning on a non-show day. We strolled right in around 9 am and only shared the joint with maybe 5 other tables.

Service was exceptional - from our waitress to the kitchen staff that delivered the food, everyone was fantastically friendly. The food was average - but I went with the normal bacon and eggs rather than trying any of their unique offerings like the meatloaf omelette or the breakfast burrito. I plan on coming back and doing that!

This location is sparkly new compared to the other location and I loved our table right next to the window with a beautiful view of Grand Center.
We ate here on a a Saturday morning.  The breakfast was good. My husband would have liked another egg for the price and my biscuit was a little dry. Other than that, we enjoyed it.

Not a lot of favorable reviews here, but I liked it.  Stopped in for breakfast Saturday morning.  It's got a nice, current ambience, service was good, the food was good and the prices were pretty standard. 

It's always nice to know of a good breakfast place that isn't packed on Saturday morning.  Nothing worse than waiting for a table at Bob Evans.  ;-p  Probably two-thirds of the tables remained empty the whole time I was there last Saturday.  

I had a breakfast sandwich and it was HUGE (get a side of potatoes and it's enough for two, especially if you're not a big eater).  There are lots of options here, although the menu offered a croissant and maybe three different cheeses, I got rye and gouda, neither of which was listed.  I appreciated the flexibility.   

No need to hurry over and check it out, but if you're looking for a decent Sat. morning breakfast alternative, I recommend it.

Well we tried to go here on a Tuesday night (around 6:30pm) and they do not have hours listed anywhere and door was unlocked And the staff said no we are closed. Their website/Facebook/Yelp even says open until 10pm. poor advertising, customer service, they new to post something saying we close early. I guess the other city diner on S Grand will just keep getting our business!! Sad too it was going to be our first time trying there but it looks like it was and will be our last.

Grabbed a quick piece of their banana nut bread with orange cream cheese for breakfast.  It was pretty good and I really liked the way that the top of the piece (where all the nuts were located) became slightly crispy.

I have a hard time going more than 3 stars based on having only tried a side dish.  I may dig deeper into their menu if I find myself back there again but I did notice that the prices seemed a bit high for a place billing themselves as a diner.

Super heart the diner in South City...so had to try this one. I loved the atmosphere and the decor with a super rad old school TV. We sat at the bar and the bartender was so awesome. I had the meatloaf omelet and it was scrumptious, amazing for a hangover. The only problem was the coffee being a little too expensive and tasting burnt. We asked for another and they gave it to us right away. Bonus...check out the race car track in the window...heart south city diner.

This was the worst restaurant I've been to in a long time. The waiters are horrible and so are the managers.Our table was so small that we could nearly fit our plates on the table and the dishes sat there while we waited 30mins for our check. We waited 2 hours for chicken fingers and almost got into a physical altercation with our waiter. When we confronted the manager about our waitress behavior, she proceeded to deny any problems we had stating that "she is the best waitress at the restaurant". If thats true, then I would hate to see the other waiters. Worst dinning experience ever.

I like to try to come here before Fox shows, because then I don't feel bad about having a drink and then walking two doors down to the show. The bartender is cool, he makes a great Old Fashioned. It does get crowded, which sucks because this has caused me to leave and try to eat elsewhere before the show. I've also come for breakfast on Saturdays, when it's pretty empty and you can get a good diner breakfast. Their onion rings are tasty.

Me and a companion went to dine here Sunday morning around 10am. When we arrived, there were seats available, and we were promptly seated. After being seated, we waited for our server, who took a good 10 minutes to show up (meanwhile the other waiter must've passed us a good 10-15 times). My boyfriend ordered pineapple juice, and I just requested water. When the juice arrived, I noticed the distinct brownish yellow color, and hoped my suspicions would be wrong. He asked me to taste it- it tasted like old Vess pineapple soda, as in watered down, artificial and disgusting. We asked our waitress to take it back, and she did, and also apologized. He then ordered hot chocolate , which tasted like nesquick (not sweet enough, and watered down), but decided to leave it at that. 
After looking at the menu, I noticed there were no options to mix and match pancakes and eggs or meat of any sort. I asked our waitress if I could add pancakes to an order of omelets, and she said that would not be possible - no customizations can be made. I also discovered that a 6 dollar order of pancakes only included 3 pancakes. I ordered banana pecan pancakes to split, my companion ordered an western omelet platter with cubed potatoes. It took about 15-20 minutes before our food arrived. My companion's arrived first, with hash browns, not cubed potatoes. These were promptly replaced. My plate arrived shortly after, with regular (not banana pecan) pancakes. I brought it to the attention of the server, and she promptly replaced them as well, at least leaving us the original pancakes. She was also not attentive, and didn't check on us throughout the service. I often had to call for her as she passed us to get her attention for drink refills, or requests for silverware.

Overall, food was great. 
I don't know if the cooks generally mess up orders, or if ours were put in wrong, but that aspect definitely left something to be desired.
A cheeseburger for her that was way overcooked, and a mid-day slinger for me that was not good. Should have gone to Dooley's!

Yeah I think I am pretty much done with this location. The past 3 or 4 times I have been the service has seriously been lacking and the food has a left a lot to be desired but last night just really solidified the fact that they do not really seem to care about that. 

J and I were super hungry after serving ice cream all night. It was about 11 on Friday night so we thought City Diner was the perfect spot to get some food. We walked inside and saw multiple tables open so we thought we had come at a great time. We stood by the hostess stand for 10 minutes while a few frazzled employees kept running by without even a small acknowledgment. We tried to get a few peoples attention but the most we got was a stare by a waitress and then she went on with what she was doing. Finally a couple who was walking out told us they had been sitting at the bar so there was now 2 seats available there. Perfect. We sat down at the very small bar and I cleaned up all of the empty plates/drink glasses from the previous customers. The bartender saw us, smiled but then walked away. Um. Ok. He disappeared for 5 minutes and came back with waters for another party at the end of the bar. I tried to flag him down so I could at least get a water and put in some type of order but I was completely ignored. I understand being busy, I have worked in a lot of customer service rolls in my life but would it kill them to let us know "We are really busy but I will be right with you." I don't know, something that says hey we see you, we appreciate you are here and will get with you asap. I think that is not much to ask for. So after another 10 minutes we left. We were there almost 30 minutes total without getting acknowledgment from any waiter, bartender, hostess, etc. and without getting menus or waters. We walked over to Dooley's and got some of the best service we have had in a while. Sorry City Diner I am so over you.

Dinner with the boys to celebrate a good start to the school year. We had a BLT with French Fries, Cheeseburger with Onion Rings, and Caesar Salad. All were tasty but our favorites were the Strawberry and Chocolate Milkshakes along with great customer service by James our waiter. Under new ownership, we cannot wait to come back and check out their new menu which unveils tomorrow. Check this place out!!  only knocked a star off for the higher than I like prices.

By far the worst dining experience I never had. Granted it was a holiday and we were a party of 12, and granted they had problems with the power outage that was resolved by the time we arrived at about 11:10 a.m. We waited a while to be seated and then they came and took our order at about a quarter to 12.  After nearly an hour we started asking about our food. The whole time we had been there no one talked with us about the delay. At 1:30, after assurances for at least 15 minutes that our order was being worked on, and after watching food come out for tables seated at least an hour after us, we left.  All the waiter could tell us was "I'm sorry", "It's no under my control" "it's not just you guys, all the people in my section are getting no food" yada, yada.  So what's with your section, because everybody else's section is getting food? Are you just totally inept in managing your diners? I'll never go back.  My little 5 year old granddaughter says she'll never go back to that place again. Dine at your own risk. If I could give zero stars I definitely would.
Went for lunch once. It was just standard. Nothing special. Great location near SLU and all the theaters.

The original needs to watch out, this new location is fantastic. 
Our service was fast and friendly. The menu selection is a little smaller then South Grand location, but they put out some good diner food. 
I live in between the two locations, and I may now find myself preferring the Fox diner over the original.

Went here for breakfast during my six week stay in St. Louis. I love dive places and diners so this was right up my alley. It's a very laid-back place, good atmosphere. I sat at the bar and was helped immediately. I ordered a slinger and it was amazing, even better than the one I had at Fitz's. Even though it was a smaller portion, I definitely still left there full. I recommend this restaurant if you're in the area and want a good, cheap breakfast.

Went to the Fox to see Kinky Boots and ate at City Diner before the show. We got seated in an annex area of the restarunt which was the hallway of the next building. Kind of odd and uninviting area.
Waiter was mediocre at best and the food was not that great either.
I would recommend eating somewhere else before getting to the Fox but in a pinch it isn't horrible.

I would not waste my time eating here!   The pancakes are terrible tasting and mine came out almost burned! Everyone else at the table had pancakes that were not burned, thank goodness!  The only PLUS to eating here is the proximity to the Fox Theater.  Next time, we will probably try somewhere else.

We tried the City Diner at the Fox a year ago and experienced terrible service--slow, uninterested, rude. We sat for 40 minutes waiting for our food, while our waiter chatted by the counter, holding our plates. Our food was cold.

Yesterday, we tried it again because we were in the area and needed to eat. We walked in and there was no hostess. We tried to make eye contact with the 2 waiters in the back. They looked over and never signaled to us. Finally, one said to wait just a minute. Then he proceeded to take a few orders, fill drinks, and run a tab. A waitress then said she'd be with us. Then she got some wine, water, and beers for 3 different tables. She brought food to 2 tables and stopped to chat with someone in the back. She finally came over to us and said they were short staffed that night. We were standing at the entryway for 15 minutes, arms full of bags and kids, with an empty 4 top right in front of us. The first waiter then said we would have to wait a while, and when we asked about the empty table, he said it needed to be cleaned. We waited again. The waitress put our menus down on the dirty table, then the waiter made us lift them up so he could spray the table.

We sat and waited--no water, no drink orders. We finally packed up and got ready to leave. While we stood with our coats on, the waiter came over and asked us IF we wanted something to drink. We left.

We love the south Grand City Diner--the service is usually fast and good, and the food is consistent. City Diner at the Fox is a huge disappointment.

I really wanted to give this place at least 4 stars but in fairness to other places, 3 is all it gets.  I've driven by this place many times on my way to the Loop from downtown and always wanted to go, so in my first act when going into vacation mode (no more work because of Christmas) I stopped by.  

Very much like the interior, very cool.  Granite bar top, lava lamps at the tables, modern with a twist.  Menu items are basic but good.  Service, while very friendly, was a bit distracted and maybe somewhat inexperienced.  The food I ordered was very good but was under temp, and I let them know (meatloaf and mashed potatoes).  Breakfast all day, open since June.  Definitely worth a visit and I would go back to give them a second try.  Next to the Fox.
Good food, Great atmosphere and staff was very helpful.  Place is kinda small and seemed to stay busy however they where on top of it.   I would go back again if in the area.

I'm a single guy working downtown.  I like to cook but cooking for one is a hassle, no fun at all and relatively expensive since half the stuff you buy, is never used and it goes to waste. Right now I have 5 half full cartons of old milk in my frig waiting to be thrown away.  So, I eat out most the time, and when I don't have plans with friends (ie can't get someone to have dinner with me) I like places I can hit on my way home from work, get a meat plus two and then head home.  no muss, no fuss. 

Well, the legendary City Diner on South Grand has opened a new sister location next to the Fox and it's great!  (and between my office and home).

Classic American diner food taken a step up and served in a very hip urban space with a full liquor license -- what more can a guy as for!  The vibe in this place is really cool. 

This is the best diner food you will ever have and it's inexpensive.  Meat plus two under $10.  

They just opened and are in the middle of the soft opening.  I stopped bye tonight on my way home from work and the place was packed with people grabbing a bite before Wicked at the Fox.  

Don't let shows at the Fox stop you from going.  There is plenty of parking on the side street at the meters.   Restaurants in Grand Center have gotten the city to extend the meters to 9 or 10 with the max time limited to 90 minutes.  The point of this -- besides making more money for the city -- is to force Fox patrons in the thousands of parking spots around the theater so those of use who want to eat at one of the restaurants can find a place to park for 75 cents.  And meter people are out every night at 9 writing tickets.

This place was conveniently located to all the happenings of Midtown and SLU, so we ate here. I wasn't too happy with our food and our waiter was very friendly, but a bit strange... probably overly friendly in the sense he just needed someone to chat with. Our group is cool, so we didn't mind. Though because of the food and price, I wouldn't come back if I were in the area even with it being convenient.

I will never, I repeat, NEVER eat here again! I love the City Diner on Grand so I thought I would try this one out on a late Saturday/early Sunday with some friends. I ordered biscuits and gravy with a side of bacon and when it came to the table I sat in shock at how disgusting it looked but I thought I would give it a chance (my friend ordered the same meal also). We both took a bite and couldn't believe how awful it was. We described it as a hoagie bun covered in gravy! It was NOT a biscuit. I also thought it was 3.99 as stated on the menu but the waitress didn't inform us that there was a half order and full order so our "biscuits" were HUGE....picture a hoagie cut in half and covered in gravy....ugh! And the bacon was TINY and burnt. I am not a picky eater in the slightest so for me to be disgusted and compelled to write a negative review is a big deal. I can't believe I wasted $15 on such slop!

I took my 3.5 year old here for lunch prior to the 8/31 matinee of the Lion King. (We're talking Friday of Labor Day weekend, the final weekend the show was in town.) After reading the reviews, I was a little nervous about this choice but I didn't see anything else that was as kid friendly and convenient to the Fox. Yes, we waited roughly 25 min for a two-toper. However, given the small size of this place and the number of people ahead of us when we arrived, I think this is pretty stellar. By the time we left (roughly 20 min before the show), there was no one waiting and some tables were empty.  With the small size of this place, it seemed like the staff was working hard to turn over tables as quickly as possible. I ordered soup and had it within 90 seconds. I had an excellent roasted vegetable sandwich and my daughter had the mac 'n cheese. She eventually ate it but I would have appreciated a warning that it was going to come out with parsley on top. Took some convincing to get the kid to eat that! Our server was clearly busy but did a great job of being attentive and bringing us our items quickly.  I can absolutely see why this place has had so many negative reviews but at least in my experience, it's not for lack of effort from the staff. You can absolutely have a great experience here as long as you come in with reasonable expectations.

I went with a friend to the City Diner after a tour of the Fox. The atmosphere is fun and retro, and the location can't be beat. 

The food was very blah. I had a simple burger and fries, which should be the specialty of any diner - and the fries were limp and bland. I didn't even finish them - and that's saying a lot - I love fries! The hamburger was pretty boring as well.

The service, however, was top-notch. We loved our waiter, even though he was a bit slow. His awesome personality made up for the lack of speed. 

All in all, it's a nice place to pop in after you visit the Fox, and it's a St. Louis staple. Enjoy the ambiance and friendly waitstaff - but don't get too hung up on the food.

Excellent steak hamburgers here. If you like Steak 'n' Shake burgers, well, the burgers here are even better.

I like to eat here whenever I come to the area to catch an afternoon show.

I like South City diner. When my sister bought us tickets to go see WICKED, I asked her if she wanted to go to eat before the show. I remembered City Diner at the Fox, and that is where we decided to go. 

This location is like the stuck up pretentious cousin to South city diner. 

They were busy when we go there. One show let out, one show waiting to start. The wait was about 20 minutes about 3-5 min later a couple got up from the bar. we grabbed a couple of the seats the bar. I realize that the bartender/waiter was super busy. He wasn't unfriendly, but he could have been friendlier. 

i wanted toasted rav's and they were out. :(
I ordered a Bacon Cheeseburger w/ fried egg and fries. the burger and fries were awesome. I find it funny that I complain at Denny's for charging $4 for 2 eggs then i come here and I am charged $1.75 for one egg. News Flash I can buy a whole carton of eggs for that price.

I wish they would be open 24 hours. I would go back. the food was good.

After seeing Wicked at the Fox last night, we decided to try City Diner for a late night bite and drink.  Looks great inside...really bright and diner chic.

We sidled up to the counter and saw that they have three beers on tap and a decent selection of spirits.  We were quickly greeted by a friendly bartender who got us our drinks (and handed us menus) right away.

The menu has a wide variety of selections, but is not overwhelming.  Typical diner fare from breakfast items, to soup, salad, and sandwiches.  We both opted for the french onion soup and ordered a BLT to go for the hubby.  Soup was not spectacular, but it really hit the spot!  The BLT was great!  They had definitely just fried the bacon before assembling it and it was crispy and delicious.  The hubby downed it in no time flat.

I left wanting to try most of the other menu items. ..they all looked tasty.  I will definitely be back to this place and can see it becoming one of my local haunts.

Wow, there's a lot of negativity in these reviews, but after my experience on a Thursday morning for breakfast, I'd definitely go back. I sat down at the counter and got service relatively quickly, even though it was quite bustling w/ only one waitress on the floor. As far as the food... first, and critically, coffee was shockingly good! I enjoyed a half-order of biscuits & gravy w/ a side of bacon. The biscuit was HUGE & square w/ a lot of sausage gravy accompanied by thick, well-cooked bacon. Regarding customer service, the customer base in the morning was quite diverse in age and ethnicity, and it appeared to me that everyone received equal service. Honestly, I don't expect to get super-zippy service at a diner, and it's clear they don't have an efficient cashing out procedure. If you have time to relax, people watch, and munch on diner fare, you'll enjoy a City Diner breakfast.

This review is from my nephew - his first time at the Diner (before the symphony) he found the onion rings to be the "best" he's ever had! 
He found the cheeseburgers to be a little too big (we should stick to the kids' menu) I loved them & also the Cuban sandwich which I've had on other visits.
Plus we saw a musician eating at the bar that now is on stage! Celebrity sighting!

I'm glad I was able to say I've been here for brunch, but I won't come back.  The food was all fine, just nothing special.  I probably could have made the same things at home that tasted the same, if not better, than City Diner's meal and saved myself the drive out there.  The decor was unique and fun, cute spot near the Fox.  Even though there wasn't a wait, the waitress made our group wait until EVERYONE was there in order to be seated (hate that!) and our waitress was fine but there were a few times none of us had drinks.  My hubby had the breakfast burrito wrap which was a little overdone with the whole 'mexican' theme.....I mean beans are fine, but they were poured all over the plate and the burrito was just kind of sitting in slop.  It tasted ok, nothing special.  He said the tortilla wrap was his favorite part of the meal.  He got a side of biscuits and gravy which was ok, very soupy.  I got the breakfast platter which was fine, but I will say the bacon was very yummy!!  Glad we came to check it off the list of brunch spots we want to visit, but there are plenty of places that are better!

We go here every time we see a show at the Fox. It's cheap, fast and comfortable. The food isn't five star type it's your typical diner food. 

Service can be slow so don't be in a hurry and give yourself some wiggle room. But if you're expecting super fancy food don't eat here. 

I usually get a salad of some sort or the veggie burger and they are always awesome. Salads are a real sticky point for me with eateries and if they have soggy or brow lettuce it's a no go. Never had that problem here, their food is properly prepared and also having a finicky digestive system not once have I ever gotten sick here. Which is another big point for me and my family. 

I will always come back here and I recommend it to anyone!

Went to City Diner at the Fox at 330 on a Saturday.  Not a busy time of day and very few people in the restaurant.  We were seated immediately, and told someone would be right out.  5 minutes later, and nobody had said even a word to us, never mind taken a drink order.  At 10 minutes, we stood up and told the hostess that we were going else where, since no one had served us.  Her response (which was the most maddening) was: Oh, ok.  

Horrible experience.  Will not be back. Do not recommend to anyone.

This is my second time round and both times before a performance at the Fox.  It gets busy!  So arrive at least an hour and a half before the show.  The food is consistent.  I got the Build a Breakfast.  Its a lot of food.  Quality is just ok.  There always seems to be extra wait time for food.

Nutshell:  moderately priced, ok food, I'll probably be looking elsewhere first.

Cool 80's music and retro diner feel. Also some decent meatless options.    Food was okay. But service was terrible and the place filled up with rude, non-tipping youngsters. That probably explains the service...

Even though I am a regular here, I have only one check-in. I am biased on two counts: they opened this North Grand location--nearer my house, and the interior is what I would have in my own home if I could. 

Food is always good. They removed my favorite item, however: the fried egg sandwich and replaced it with a pricier, croissant, egg, cheese and meat version.

I ordered the two eggs with toast and potatoes and put my egg on the toast as before, for $1.25 less.
They get pretty busy on weekend mornings, but the service and food has been good, fast and consistent every time.

Had a great quick meal! The reuben was a 9/10.... I love my Reuben's and they had the perfect balance of meat and sauerkraut. Our server Jenny worked her butt off catering to the rush that came shortly after a show. Our water glasses stayed refreshed and the bill was cheap.

i was contacted by the owner about my review and asking me how to make my experience better next time. I do like when the business owners reach out to their customers. so, i felt the need to post my reply.

    i understand that when we were there it was an unusual night. it was a Sunday and in between the matinee and the night time showing of WICKED. I work in a service industry and understand when you are super busy sometimes people are not at their friendliest. the only service issue i had was that after quite a long time with an empty glass of tea. I finally had to ask him for a refill.  
    I am always stunned by the price of an egg now. I understand the labor and delivery costs, but that is like the popcorn prices at the movies. 
     overall, it was a good experience. and i will return and give the fox location another try. I even felt bad for the guy when the girl sitting next to me left him a 40 cent tip, and gave him a few extra dollars on the tip.

Great location to The Fox. 

Food was mediocre. Had the Cuban sandwich. It tasted microwaved. Salad was plain. Malt did not at all taste like there was malt in it.  I would avoid the shakes. They were icy and mostly tasteless. 

I'd probably give them one more shot, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.

Diner nostalgia meets the urban scene scape of St. Louis... Surprise, it's a diner! Though still a favorite of mine to go grab a late night snack by the Fabulous Fox Theatre and watch the passers go by. Décor is city sheik, and the food prices are reasonable. All the popular, regular standby 'standards' you'd fine at any surviving diner here in the US, but a smaller selection. Go for the architecture, and enjoy a Cup of Joe. For me, a nice place to immerse oneself in the city scene without all the fanfare!

Had the slinger, it was awesome!  Friendly staff and good prices.  The bathrooms were clean.  The French fries were very interesting, it was like they dipped them in the french toast batter and then fried them.  I liked it.
Awesome food! Cubed potatoes are the best! Fun atmosphere and very attentive staff make this a great spot to grab a good meal!

3rd time trying and 1st time successfully getting in here before or after a show at the Fox. Expected it to be great considering how busy they always appear to be. Slow.....took 20 minutes to get onion rings. Didn't stick around for an entree.

The Southsider is where it's at.  Biscuits N Gravy, scrambled eggs and hash browns, what more does a man need?  Biscuits were good and tasted fresh, gravy was hot and flavorful, scrambled eggs were fluffy and the hash browns were seasoned well.  

When I'm in the area for breakfast, this it where I'll go.

Grabbed breakfast here.   Very typical diner food.   Very typical breakfast food.   The ambiance is retro or hip.    Had an interesting "southern".   It was eggs, hash browns, and biscuits with sausage gravy.   Really my favorite order ever.    Eggs were a little over cooked.   The biscuits were huge pan type?  Ok.   The hash browns were slightly tasteless.    The sausage gravy was decent.   
Expected so much more flavor.   Whole thing was just ok.   Had the same at Denny's.
Good food. Good service. Cool manager. Cool place.  Did I say this place is cool? It is!  And it is perfect for before or after THE FOX. GO!!!

Went in for breakfast as we love checking out diners. Food was good, service was okay. Benches had tape on them to cover holes and the server dropped the check off and took 20 mins to come back. Still worth a good breakfast and definitely a better choice than what we were considering (Triumph) which was dead.

Tried to have dinner at Lucha across the street. Lousy service and walked out. Went to City Diner instead. Fantastic atmosphere. Fantastic burger. Fantastic counter service from Danny! I wish I lived here. I would come in all the time.

Five stars for yummy diner food and excellent service! Friday night around 10pm was a great time to go grab some grub. Burger was like a thicker version of steak 'n shake's...mmm... and fries were awesome! My boyfriend said his slinger tasted "healthier" (if that's possible) ...not super greasy, which he loved. I love the decor of this place. I've been there in the past before a show at the Fox. I'd definitely like to come back and check out their brunch menu!
The service was good and friendly, but wow do they use a crappy grade of ground beef.  More suited to dog food. I won't be back and I really wanted to like this place.

A classic diner with less than classic fare. 
When we got here they were busy but found a spot at the bar for us pretty quickly. We reviewed the menu under the watchful eye of the bartender. When we ordered drinks we asked that he use his best judgement and make us something good. For my lovely partner he made a fruity martini, for me he suggested 3 Blind Mice stout. Both were good choices. 

I ordered the Slinger it is a shame pile that comes with eggs, sausage and hash browns covered with chili and cheese. It was actually quite good. My wife ordered the biscuits and gravy and it was bad. And by bad I mean really not good. Little tip sausage gravy does not really mean sausage gravy colored jell-o. If you do go then stay away from the biscuits, get the slinger. It is just the right amount of fat, grease, and empty carbs to satisfy your drunk ass that late at night. 

Now onto the staff. They were a little slow with getting our order taken care of but the bartender did keep checking on it and when it took more time than he thought was acceptable he decided to comp our first round of drinks. Very nice bartender and he means well. I would avoid asking anything about religion or for instance if the woman sitting next to you says anything about religion feel free to punch her in the back of the head to shut her up as that starts the bartender down a path that makes your meal a little awkward. Other than that we enjoyed our late night.

Grabbed a late breakfast after turning down a long line outside crown candy kitchen.  City diner had wonderfully friendly service. The milkshakes were delicious, especially the raspberry. I had the garden veggie omelette with diced potatoes, after ordering hash browns :/ It was an average omelette that required some extra zest, but the only hot sauce offered was Tabasco. Ketchup was added. 

The vegetarian eggs Benedict with tomato was above par with tasty hollandaise sauce. Coffee refills were abundant and the decor was modern, yet retro. The menu was full of good looking American cuisine choices, but I will probably not be returning to city diner.
House Balsamic is very tasty on the salad and the chili cheese hot dog is very good and highly recommended. The service was quick and hospitable

Located in the heart of the arts district in Midtown, the City Diner serves up good  toasted ravioli, a St. Louis favorite.  The chili seemed like it came out of a can, however. Also, our server seemed bit odd...he was overly nice but perhaps just was excited to speak with tourists visiting his fair city.  If I had the option to go to the other restaurants nearby, I probably would choose them over city diner.

We had a great late Sunday morning breakfast here! I ordered the Make A Breakfast, and our waiter was very attentive in making sure the meal was exactly as I wanted, down to every substitution and special request. The french toast was killer and the hash browns were hot and perfectly crunchy, just how I like them. I would definitely return to check out lunch or dinner options; the meal was great!

Tops in my opinion. Tons of dogz to choose from. Lots of different sauces etc. operator is friendly and fast. Hands out free can koozies sometimes also. This is located inside the exit area of Home Depot which is somewhat inconvenient but worth stopping in if you like dogs!
One of St. Louis' best kept secrets. Yummy hot dogs (with turkey and veggie options for non meat eater like me) delicious Carmel popcorn and the guys working there are always so friendly and nice.

It used to be real good now it is just OK.  I can get similar dogs for the same price now elsewhere.  The guy making the dogs was friendly enough and the toppings plenty but I don't think it has the same zing it was had for me.  Unless I am at Home Dept and am hungry it will no longer be a destination lunch.

Hotdogs are my favorite food and I like to try out local hotdog spots when I travel to different cities. I used Yelp to find a spot in St. Louis and I discovered Dirty Dogz. The surprise of it all was it is inside the Home Depot! I got 2 small chili dogs with onions and sauerkraut. They were DELICIOUS! The buns and wieners are made for Dirty Dogz and that is a nice touch. I will definitely be back!

Stumbled upon this place completely by accident.  Glad we did!

Hot dogs: made special for them.
Buns: made special for them.
Condiments: over 200 available...help yourself.

The wife and I sat on the bench after completing a project that found us a healthy distance away from our usual Home Depot hot dog.  Should we?  We did and we're glad we did.  This doesn't mean we love Steve's take on the Chicago dog any less, it just means that we've found another HD hot dog we can enjoy when we're not in our regular HD.  I think that should be alright.   

The dog itself was a nice blend of the usual hot dog flavors.  The sport peppers were a bit hotter than what I'm used to seeing for sport peppers but they worked.  The bun was a lot different than the typical poppyseed bun to which I am accustomed but it worked well also.  I would characterize it as a slightly less buttery version of a brioche.  It seemed to class-up the dog quite a bit.

As for the 200+ condiments, I've been eating my hot dogs one way since I was a little kid and I didn't deviate.  For those who like hot sauce or fancy mustard on a hot dog, you'll be in heaven though.

Who goes to #homedepot to get a #hotdog ... This Girl! #dirtydogz is definitely worth the stop for the bun alone!!! I could seriously just have a bunch of toppings and the fresh bun (made custom for them). I am usually not a fan of steamed​ hot dogs (prefer grilled) but I have to give them a thumbs up...they were good. I had the Dirty Dog and the St. Louis Style (provolone cheese sold me). #stl #hotdogstand #brentwoodmo #stlfood #stlfoodie #stlmetrofoodie

Ok. When you become a go-to place to cure a craving you must be good. I could have stopped at a local gas station but wanted to give this place another chance. 

And I am glad I did.

I sit here enjoying the great combinations of flavors on a fresh bun. Yum.

Not sure why this place has such good reviews.  The hot dog was fair, there were many selections, but in the end it wasn't exceptional.  The bun was good and the employee running the stand was very nice. We ordered a Chicago style dog and a slaw dog, the toppings were good, but the hotdog itself was just average. I felt the price was a little steep for what I got.
GREAT place for a quick lunch. Fast & friendly service. Credit cards accepted. Good selection of beverages no alcohol. Variety of dogz w/tons of toppings. Dogz start at $4. recommend the 1/4lb dog.

I decided to hit the stand again since I needed some new bulbs for our fridge.  Home Depot parking wasn't too bad and it wasn't too busy so I made good time getting to the stand. I was reading the menu while another customer was being taken care of.  Got a kick out of the deal for Cubs fans!

When it came to order I tried the Big Al.  A 10"+ sausage covered with chili, cold creamey coleslaw, and onions.  We chatted about the cubs sign and other things while by lunch was being prepared.  Again, a very nice, personable staff. I made the stand-alone dog in to a meal with soda and chips.  They have a good selection of sodas to choose from.  

I took my stuff to the car sat down (took a photo of course) and proceeded to attack the dog with a fork. The flavor combination was good.  It tasted like all three ingredients belonged together.  Nothing was overpowering, all were very complementary.  But there was a slight problem.

My food was just warm.  I expected both the sausage to be warmer as well as the chili covering it.  Maybe it was due to the coleslaw? To be fair it was just 40F outside and I had to walk about 10 yards to my car. I scrapped chili and slaw out of the way to feel the temperature of the sausage.  Warm, close to room temperature, not hot.  I then stuck my finger in the chili and reached the same conclusion. It was too close to "warm" for me.  I prefer my food to be at a higher temperature.  I didn't bother to finish about 1/2 of it.

Again, service was great but the food was just OK.

TL: DR - inside the exit corridor of home Depot. No frills, but surprisingly amazing food for a food stand. Few warm seating options in the winter, outside picnic table in the summer.

I can't believe I'm writing a review for a hot dog stand, but this place really is amazing. You have to be some kind of special to make a living on a hot dog stand. But this really is my go to place for a hot dog, I've been to Steve's hot dogs in Tower Grove and found their hot dogs almost too big and ended up having to eat them with a fork and knife like a casserole dish. First off, this place is inside the exit corridor of home depot. Dirty dogs has great combinations, ample toppings, and still allows me to eat my hot dog like a civilized human being eating a hot dog outside a Home Depot.

They have like 20 sauces (i.e., mustards, ketchups, and hot sauces) you can top your hot dog with, I really ever go for like the same 4, and sometimes you don't want any of the sauces cuz it'll mess with your existing toppings. Plus the sauces look a bit old. But what really makes this place is their super soft buns, o geez... Anyways, I've had the chilli dog (amazing), the jalapeno and cream cheese dog (surprisingly amazing), and the St Louis (provel and pizza sauce) dog (not surprisingly bad). The gf always gets the Chicago dog and loves it, craves it dare I say.

Few other things to note, if it's winter time (which today was), there's not always a warm place to eat. Sometimes they have a bench inside (today they did not). If it's warm enough though, they usually have a picnic table outside. 

Decor, it's home depot-y. Price, not bad, bout $3.50 for a regular grocery store Frank with all the fixins, and about $5 for a larger dog with all the fixins.

Every time I come to Home Depot I can smell the amazing aroma of HOT DOGS! it smells insanley delicious no matter what isle I am in. Every time I walk out of Home Depot I stare and drool at the Hot Dog stand BUT I never ate any because a Hot Dog stand inside a Home Depot is a bit sketchy no? Well one afternoon shopping while starving I caved and bought a Hot Dog! 4 words my friends, Best Hot Dog Ever!!!!

I had the Chicago dog with the sport peppers and all the works and then of course I condimented (to put an excessive amount of condiments on something) the heck out of my Hot Dog with different mustard, ketchup, seasonings and sauces. I sat my tush on the bench and ate with an appetite of a 100 lions. It was really really delicious!

The man that owns the stand is incredibly nice and friendly and I hope he brings a Hot Dog stand downtown!
Hot dogs, kielbasa, brats, 1/2 smokes done right.  Mustard & condiment bar, fresh sauerkraut.

My family had lunch on the bench outside Home Depot on Sunday. We ate hot dogs and drank Fitz's root beer. We didn't even step foot inside the Home Depot to purchase anything. Just went their for the Dirty Dogz!

The best. Friendly staff. So many options, but also a great menu to help steer you in a tasty direction.

I plan my weekend Home Depot trips around lunch time to get some hot dogs on the way out. Nearly every time I come. I go to the Brentwood Home Depot where these guys are instead of Lowe's down the street simply because of these hot dogs. Home Depot Brentwood ought to know that. 

I've certainly come here for lunch without needing to go to Home Depot.

I moved here a few years ago, needed some stuff at HD, and was hungry and figured I'd rather a hot dog than McDonalds across the parking lot and was blown away. From there on out, I'm hooked and tell everyone about it. People are skeptical when I tell them that one of my favorite hot dog places is in the exit vestibule at Home Depot.

They have a table completely covered with bottles of BBQ and hot sauces. I try a new one just about every time.

I won't be going back. In fact, I regret even trying this place.

To begin, the menu does not match what is published all over the internet. When I asked the owner she said that they were planned for the future! What is currently on the menu are basically sandwiches. I was extremely disappointed that what I had planned to eat was not offered on the restaurant's real menu. My husband ordered soup, which was on the menu, only to be told that they did not have it that night. The food service was very slow to the table even though we were the only diners in the restaurant. When I finally did receive my appetizer it was the wrong item. When the waitress brought the right item, it was cold. Then my entree came without the side of tostones (which I never did get). Then the bill came and I was charged twice as much for my beverage as I should have been. 

Overall the food quality was just below mediocre.

Authentic Dominican cuisine in a quiet atmosphere. This restaurant is being discovered and is well worth the visit. The chef is inventive, the food delicious, plentiful and unique. We have been back multiple times. They now have a two-way liquor license. Decor is not posh, but I go there to eat, not comment on the interior decorating

Asked the waitress if they had any salad options because everything on the menu had carbs in it - waitress told us about the California and Santa Fe salads. I ordered the California salad and was told it would take awhile to prepare, longer than menu entrees. Why?

When it came out I was underwhelmed with what I got - a bowl of lettuce with corn and a few fried tortilla strips (no protein). The dressing was good but the bill was $12 and I left feeling hungry.... 

Also, the receipt said the salad was ordered with "No meat". I wasn't given the option to add meat or else I would have.... to ensure I'd feel satiated. I wonder if the salad would be more than $12 if I asked for meat. hmm...

I was downtown Monday and a friend recommended stopping in at Oso's for lunch.  From the look of the place, it seemed like it must be new and is still improving the decor.  A large notice on the front window (I assume they are awaiting a license for drinks) made me think they were closed initially, but they do have a neon sign saying when they are open.  So, I went on in and grabbed a seat.  

I was greeted promptly and given a menu.  I explained that it was my first time here and could use help picking something from the Honduran/Dominican menu.  The host was very helpful and explained that they have a list of foods from both nationalities as well as more Americanized items like Cuban Sandwiches.  

With his help, I went with the Pollo Guizado with moro and salad.  The Pollo Guizado is described as Chicken Stew.  The moro is a traditional rice and bean side dish that took on an orange color from the seasonings.  

When the meal came out, the chicken and rice/beans were mixed together.  The chicken stew did not come with a broth, so it was more like a slow roasted dish.  Please note that to enhance the savoriness of the flavor, they use the back bone/neck of the chicken in the roasting.  So, watch out for small vertebra and cartilage pieces before chomping.  I assume the hoofed proteins don't have to carry this caution.

The flavors of both dishes (since I ate them together on each bite) were deep and savory without being overwhelming.  The heat level was low (intentionally).  The host mentioned that certain items can be made "hotter" with additional spices (such as the stir fry items), but that they want to appeal to more palates with their basic recipes.  

The portion size was reasonable and quite generous for lunch.  

The salad was a nice side salad size with crisp lettuce and red cabbage.  The dressing was already on the salad when served.  Fortunately, there was a correct amount of dressing to add flavor without making the salad drenched.

I also tried a Guava natural juice with lunch.  It had a bright sweet/sour flavor with a bit of tangy kick.  

Overall, I enjoyed my experience.  I think it could use a bit more decor work to make it more visually appealing.  The customer service was polite and generally good, but could pick up a few pointers like offering glasses of water to the customer and bringing out the silverware/napkins ahead of time.  Little things to make the experience more appealing.

I definitely preferred this dining experience to my first Honduran meal at a north side restaurant.

Review #160

Incredibly fresh and authentic foods.
Had the mofongo w/ steak. Tostones as a side.
Would recommend to anyone wishing to have a fresh, and authentic meal that is off the "beaten path" here in Indy.
The only possible negative is to plan accordingly for time. This is fresh made not pre-prepped on a food line.
They offer wine and beer now. Yah! Still loving Oso's. Check out my previous review for more details.

I visited Oso's for a weekday lunch after visiting on a Saturday to find it was closed with no sign on the door. First, let me start off my saying if you are expecting ambiance or anything fancy, this isn't the place to go. Also, if you check menus online before going to a restaurant, save yourself the heartbreak with this one.
